definition: Xiang Yu the Conqueror (232-202 BC), warlord defeated by first Han emperor
back of neck/item/thing/term (in a mathematical formula)/sum (of money)/classifier for principles, items, clauses, tasks, research projects etc
surname Xiang
feather/5th note in pentatonic scale

sentences.english: Xiang Yu was a Chinese general in the third century B.C. who took his troops across the Yangtze River into enemy territory and performed an experiment in decision making.
sentences.chinese: 项羽是公元前三世纪时的一位中国将军。

sentences.english: It got its name after a mysterious legend about Xiangyu.
sentences.chinese: 它的名字源于关于项羽的神秘传说。

sentences.english: Third, Liu Bang are not satisfied with the feudality from Shiang Yu.
sentences.chinese: 三是刘邦对项羽分封的不满。

sentences.english: Unable to stage a comeback, Xiangyu committed suicide at Wujiang River.
sentences.chinese: 看大势已去，项羽只好投乌江自杀。

sentences.english: And this entropy term here, when A and B come together and start mixing up.
sentences.chinese: 在熵这一项上，当A和B项羽并混合。

sentences.english: The struggle between Chu State and Han State lasted for eight years, yet he eventually failed.
sentences.chinese: 然而项羽却是个例外，楚汉相争八年，他最终失败了。

sentences.english: He had lost most of his soldiers and run out of food.
sentences.chinese: 这时，项羽手下的兵士已经很少，粮食又没有了。

definition: Liu Bang (256 or 247-195 BC), bandit leader who became first Han emperor Han Gaozu 漢高祖|汉高祖 (reigned 202-195 BC)
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]
ancient place name, in Anhui province
Xiao He (-193 BC), famous strategist and chancellor, fought on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]
Chu-Han Contention (206-202 BC), power struggle between Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] of Han and Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3] of Chu
posthumous name of the first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦 (256 or 247-195 BC), reigned 202-195 BC

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord
Bai Qi (-258 BC), famous general of Qin 秦國|秦国, the victor at 長平|长平 in 260 BC/same as 公孫起|公孙起
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
Chen Sheng (died 208 BC), Qin dynasty rebel, leader of the Chen Sheng Wu Guang Uprising 陳勝吳廣起義|陈胜吴广起义[Chen2 Sheng4 Wu2 Guang3 Qi3 yi4]
King Huai of Chu (reigned 328-299 BC)/later King Huai of Chu (reigned 208-205 BC)

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama

Cao Can (-190 BC), second chancellor of Han Dynasty, contributed to its founding by fighting on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]/also pr. [Cao2 Shen1]
Duke of Pei (i.e. 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1])
Jing Ke (-227 BC), celebrated in verse and fiction as would-be assassin of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇)
